refnamediv.refpurpose: Storage of Attributes in a Database

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The avp_db module provides a number of function that allow access to attributes stored in a database.
The module provides two features. For one, it loads attributes associated to users and URIs by means of the load_attrs function.
Additionally, it can store and load attributes in a database in so called extra attribute groups. See Extra Attribute Groups below for more on those.

refsect2.title: load_attrs (group, id)
refsect2.para: Allowed in request and failure processing.

The load_attrs() function loads the attributes assigned to a certain user or a URI. The action performed is specified by the group. It contain an attribute group prefix. The loaded attributes will be placed in that group. Additionally, it specifies the meaning of the id argument.
If the group prefix refers to one of the user groups, ie., it is $fu or $tu, the id argument contains the user ID of the user whose attributes should be loaded.
If the group prefix refers to one of the URI groups, ie., it is $fr or $tr, the id argument contains the URI whose attributes should be loaded.

refsect2.title: load_extra_attrs (group, key)
refsect2.para: Allowed in request, reply, and failure processing.
The load_extra_attrs() function loads the attributes of the extra attribute group identified by the argument group that have been stored previously with the key given by the argument key.

refsect2.title: lock_extra_attrs (group, key)
refsect2.para: Allowed in request, reply, and failure processing.
The lock_extra_attrs() function places a lock on the key given by the argument key of the extra attribute group given by the argument group.

Despite the name, the function actually enters a mutex assigned to the group. Thus, what really happens is that if you try to call the function again before unlock_extra_attrs has been called, processing will halt until such a call. It does not actually lock access to the database.
Be extra careful when using the function. If you exit from processing without calling unlock_extra_attrs, you may eventually block SER completely.
Note that currently, the mutex is on the group only and not on the key.

refsect2.title: remove_extra_attrs (group, key)
refsect2.para: Allowed in request, reply, and failure processing.
The remove_extra_attrs() deletes all attributes assigned to the key given by the argument key from the extra attribute group given by the argument group.

refsect2.title: save_extra_attrs (group, key)
refsect2.para: Allowed in request, reply, and failure processing.

The save_extra_attrs() function stores all attributes with the attribute flag stated in the extra attribute group definition given by the argument group in the database given in that group definition. The attributes will be stored using the key given by the argument key.

refsect2.title: unlock_extra_attrs (group, key)
refsect2.para: Allowed in request, reply, and failure processing.

The unlock_extra_attrs() function releaes the lock on the key given by the argument key of the extra attribute group given by the argument group previously imposed by a call to the function lock_extra_attrs.
The attr_group parameter defines a extra attribute group. See Extra Attribute Groups below for more information on the content and usage of the parameter.
The db_url parameter specifies the database to be used in form of a URL. See the module of you intended database for information on the format of the URL for that database.
The did_column parameter specifies the name of the database column for the did field.
The flags_column parameter specifies the name of the database column for the flags field.
The name_column parameter specifies the name of the database column for the name field.
The scheme_column parameter specifies the name of the database column for the scheme field.
The type_column parameter specifies the name of the database column for the type field.
The uid_column parameter specifies the name of the database column for the uid field.
The uri_attrs_table parameter specifies the name of the database table that holds the attributes assigned to URIs.
The user_attrs_table parameter specifies the name of the database table that contains the attributes assigned to users.
The username_column parameter specifies the name of the database column for the username field.
The value_column parameter specifies the name of the database column for the value field.

refsect1.title: Extra Attribute Groups
refsect1.para: Extra attributes allow it to load an arbitrary set of attributes. The set is identified by a pair of values: First, the extra attribute group defines the database where the attributes can be found. Within each group the specific attributes are identified by a key which is simply a string.

Extra attribute groups are defined through the module parameter attr_group. Each occurence of the parameter defines a group. The value of the parameter contains key/value pairs. Key and value are separated by an equals sign, several pairs are separated by a comma.

refsect2.para: The id key defines the name of the extra attribute group as it will be used to address the group in the functions.
The key must be present.
The flag key indentifies the name of the attribute flag that must be set on an attribute in order to be included in the attributes stored with the store_extra_attrs function.
The key must be present.
The flags_column key specifies the name of the database column that contains the flags field.
If the key is missing, the default of "flags" will be used.
The key_column key specifies the name of the database column that contains the key field.
If the key is missing, the default of "id" will be used.
The name_column key specifies the name of the database column that contains the name field.
If the key is missing, the default of "name" will be used.
The table key defines the name of the database table to be used for the group.
The key must be present.
The type_column key specifies the name of the database column for the type field.
If the key is missing, the default of "type" will be used.
The value_column key specifies the name of the database column for the value field.
If the key is missing, the default of "value" will be used.

refsect2.title: Example
refsect2.para: Since this all looks a bit tricky, here are two examples for the definition of a extra attribute group.

refentry.refsect1:
Database Scheme
The avp_db uses three different database schemes. The attributes associated with a user are stored in the user_attrs table. The attributes associated with a URI are stored in the uri_attrs table. Finally, the extra attributes use various tables which shall be described here as the extra_attrs table.
The user_attrs table
uid
VARCHAR(64) NOT NULL
The uid field contains the user ID of the user the attribute is assigned to. It is used as the key for lookups.
flags
INT UNSIGNED NOT NULL DEFAULT 0
The flags field is a bitfield with flags regarding the usage of the database entry. Only the DB_LOAD_SER flag in bit 0 is being used. The bit must be set in the flags field for SER to load the attribute.
name
VARCHAR(32) NOT NULL
The name field contains the name of the attribute.
type
INT NOT NULL DEFAULT 0
The type field defines the type of the attribute. If it is set to 2, the attribute is of type string. Otherwise, it is of type integer.
value
VARCHAR(255)
The value field contans the value of the attribute.
The uri_attrs table
did
VARCHAR(64) NOT NULL
The did field contains the domain ID of the domain in the domain part of the URI the attribute is assigned to. The field is used as part of the key for lookups into the table.
flags
INT UNSIGNED NOT NULL DEFAULT 0
The flags field is a bitfield with flags regarding the usage of the database entry. Only the DB_LOAD_SER flag in bit 0 is being used. The bit must be set in the flags field for SER to load the attribute.
username
VARCHAR(64) NOT NULL
The username field contains the username part of the URI the attribute is assigned to. The field is used as part of the key for lookups into the table.
name
VARCHAR(32) NOT NULL
The name field contains the name of the attribute.
scheme
VARCHAR(8) NOT NULL DEFAULT 'sip'
The scheme field contains the scheme part of the URI the attribute is assigned to. Recognized schemes are sip, sips, and tel. The field is used as part of the key for lookups into the table.
type
INT NOT NULL DEFAULT 0
The type field defines the type of the attribute. If it is set to 2, the attribute is of type string. Otherwise, it is of type integer.
value
VARCHAR(255)
The value field contans the value of the attribute.
The Tables for Extra Attributes
This section describes the schema for the extra attribute tables. Unlike most other tables, these tables donâ€™t have a default name. Instead, the name is defined by the table key in the attr_group module parameter.
flags
INT UNSIGNED NOT NULL DEFAULT 0
The flags field is a bitfield with flags regarding the usage of the database entry. Only the DB_LOAD_SER flag in bit 0 is being used. The bit must be set in the flags field for SER to load the attribute.
key
VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL
The key field contains the key for lookups into the extra attribute table.
name
VARCHAR(32) NOT NULL
The name field contains the name of the attribute.
type
INT NOT NULL DEFAULT 0
The type field defines the type of the attribute. If it is set to 2, the attribute is of type string. Otherwise, it is of type integer.
value
VARCHAR(255)
The value field contans the value of the attribute.
